byline.contributor: Steven Erlanger reported from Paris, and Peter Baker from Washington. Somini Sengupta contributed reporting from the United Nations, Michael D. Shear from Manila, and Liz Alderman from Paris.
byline.original: By STEVEN ERLANGER and PETER BAKER

abstract: News Analysis; Islamic State's series of attacks on foreign countries has opened possibility of unlikely alliance between United States, France and Russia, each of which harbor reasons for wanting to destroy group; competing national interests and differences on range of issues, however, may threaten countries' sustained cooperation.
lead_paragraph: The United States and Russia have been drawn together against ISIS by the Paris attacks, but disagreements between them remain.

headline.main: For France, an Alliance Against ISIS May Be Easier Said Than Done

snippet: The United States and Russia have been drawn together against ISIS by the Paris attacks, but disagreements between them remain.

keywords.value: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
keywords.name: organizations
